questions.question: A young boy came to visit his mother admitted to the antenatal ward for her delivery. You arethe paediatrician on rounds in the adjacent post-natal cubical. His speech was very differentfrom a normal child. Out of curiosity, you examine his oral cavity and the following finding isseen. What would be the most likely cause of this condition?

Sirish, a young talented singer failed to make it through the Music Idol audition. Deeplyaffected by this, he drank a full bottle of a drain unclogger. He was rushed to the ER withfroth in the mouth. Which of the following could be done as the first step in treatment?

options.D: Gag the child to induce emesis349

questions.explanation: 358The recommended first step in the case of alkali ingestion (most commonly seen with drainuncloggers/house hold cleaning agents) is dilution through the administration of milk or water.Contraindications in a case of caustic (strong acid or alkali) ingestion:• Neutralization• Induced emesis•Gastric lavage

questions.question: Mala, a young student of class 9 accidentally pipettes sulphuric acid while performingvolumetric analysis in her chemistry lab. Which type of mucosal damage would you expect inher?
questions.explanation: Acid ingestion produces coagulative necrosis.Acid ingestion produces coagulative necrosis and a somewhat protective thick eschar. The amountof acidic agents usually ingested is low as they are generally bitter.Alkali ingestion: Most cases (70%) of caustic ingestions are accidental. Drain uncloggers are mostcommon as they are tasteless so more is ingested. Alkali ingestion produces liquefactive necrosis.

questions.question: A 48-hours-old boy baby born at 35 weeks of gestation regurgitates the feeds given to him.Abdominal examination reveals an airless scaphoid abdomen. A contrast study is performedand the findings are as shown below. What is the possible diagnosis?

options.A: Esophageal atresia in TEF type A
options.B: Esophageal atresia in TEF type D
options.C: Esophageal atresia in TEF type C
options.D: Esophageal atresia in TEF type B

questions.explanation: The defect demonstrated in the contrast study depicts oesophagal atresia (EA). Isolatedoesophagal atresia falls under tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) type A.Oesophagal atresia is the most common congenital anomaly of the oesophagus, >90% have anassociated TEF.Plain radiography in the evaluation of respiratory distress might reveal a coiled feeding tube in theoesophagal pouch and/or an air-distended stomach, indicating the presence of a coexisting TEF.Conversely, pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen.The following classification was given by Gross:Varietiof esophageal atresia aeoesophageal fistulaType AIsolated esophagealatresiaType C (most common)Proximal esophagealatresia distal tracheo-esophageal fistulaRProxBtracheo-esophageal fistula + distalesophageal atresiaRType DProximal and distalcheo-esophagealType E or Hweoesophageal fistula without esophageal atresiaMARROW359

questions.question: 350A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distresssoon after birth. On examination frothing at the mouth is observed. What would be theimmediate investigation of choice?

options.C: Passing a nasogastric tube with subsequent chest radiography

questions.explanation: Newborn presenting with the above features is suggestive of a case of TEF with possibleesophageal atresia. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastrictube in the esophageal pouch, as shown in the image below.Indicators of esophageal atresia with or without a tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) are a newbornpresenting with:•Early-onset respiratory distress.Frothing at the mouth and nose•History of polyhydramniosRadiological findings:• Passing a nasogastric tube with subsequent chest radiography will reveal a coiled nasogastrictube in the esophageal pouch.•If an air-distended stomach is also present, it indicates the presence of a coexisting TEF.• Pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen.

questions.question: Milind, a young child is brought to you for recurrent respiratory symptoms and dysphagia.After ruling out other causes, you suspect a vascular anomaly that could be compressing theesophagus to be causing the symptoms. A CECT is done and the findings are as shown below.Which of the following vascular anomalies is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario suggests a diagnosis of dysphagia lusoria, which is caused most likely bythe aberrant right subclavian artery. The given image suggests the presence of the right aberrantsubclavian artery.Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to extrinsic compression of the oesophagus by adevelopmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery or right-sided or360double aortic arch.

questions.question: You are a new intern posted in the department of pediatrics. The lab reports of a newbornbaby admitted to the SNCU arrive and the ABG report is as below. Which congenital anomaly351would you suspect in such a setting of electrolyte and acid-base imbalance?
questions.explanation: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, an electrolyte and acid-base imbalancecharacteristically seen in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis and plasma HCO3- is 30 mmol/L, which is in the higher range.Both these findings indicate metabolic alkalosis.Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality.i.e Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.•Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the developmentof metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).•Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodiumstimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.•••The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.• Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.•Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It iscalled paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead ofcompensating for that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.CHPS typically presents with the following:•• Non-bilious vomiting, which is progressive, maybe projectile, occurring immediately after a feed,usually presents after the 3rd week of age.• As the vomiting continues, a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ions, chloride ions, andpotassium leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.Hyperbilirubinemia is the most common clinical association of pyloric stenosis, which is alsoknown as the icteropyloric syndrome.

questions.question: A 5-week-old infant presented with non-bilious projectile vomiting and lethargy for 2 days.On abdominal examination, an olive-like mass was palpated. Barium study showed anelongated pyloric channel. Which drug is used in the first week of life can cause thispresentation?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario suggests the diagnosis of Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.Erythromycin, particularly when given in the first few weeks of life, is found to be associated withhypertrophic pyloric stenosis.Exposur DrugMalformationePost-natalErythromycinHypertrophic pyloric stenosisPre-nataThalidomi1dePhocomeliaGrossly underdeveloped or absent limbs361Exposur DrugePre-nata Phenytoin1Pre-nata1MisoprostolMalformationFetal hydantoin syndromeIntrauterine growth restriction,microcephaly, cleft palate, hypoplastic phalanges, etc.Moebius syndrome Underdeveloped VI and VII CNS resulting in facial paralysis and lateral rectus palsy

questions.question: Savitri, a 3-week-old baby is having bouts of non-bilious projectile vomiting. On examination,the child seems lethargic and dehydrated. Abdominal examination reveals visible gastricperistalsis. What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation: The presence of non-bilious vomiting and visible gastric peristalsis is highly suggestive ofcongenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis isultrasound.CHPS is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resulting in constrictionand obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3-6 weeks of age. First-born maleinfants are at the highest risk.Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass ispalpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visibleperistalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. Thecharacteristic metabolic abnormality is hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrentvomiting.Ultrasound features:• Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called 'Nipplesign'• The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervixand is sometimes referred to as the 'cervix sign'• The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric lengthof ≥16 mmIf ultrasound is inconclusive, contrast studies (barium) are performed, which demonstrate•An elongated pyloric channel (string sign),• A bulge of the pyloric muscle into the antrum (shoulder sign), and• Parallel streaks of barium seen in the narrowed channel, producing a "double tract sign."The image attached below shows the USG findings in CHPS.362Cervix signNipple signPOST2 MIN FEEDSigns in Congenital Pyloric stenosis:SignString signDouble/triple track signDiamond sign/twining recessBeak signMushroom sign/kirkin sign/umbrella signCaterpillar signShoulder signPassing of small streak of barium through pyloric canalCrowding of muscle folds inpyloric canalTransient triangular tent likecleft in mid portion of pyloriccanal with apex pointing inferiorly.Mass impression upon antrum with streak of barium pointing towards pyloric channelIndentation of base of duodenal bulb by pylorusGastric hyperperistaltic waveSRound indentation caused byhypertrophied pyloric muscle363Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric StenosisMushroomDouble/Triplesigntrack signTeat signDiamondsignBeaksignShouldersignOMARROWThe treatment of choice is Ramstedt - Frankelstedt pyloromyotomy.

questions.question: Ashwini, the mother of a young baby is concerned after she noticed straw yellow-coloredstains in her child's clothing while washing them. She brings the child to you for examination.The child has a mildly elevated temperature and the fluid comes out from the umbilicus,whenever the child strains. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The diagnosis in the above case is a urachal fistula. The clinical vigentte suggesting straw -yellowfluid (suggestive of urine) along with secondary infection (mildly elevated temperature) andpresence of fluid only on straining are all suggestive of urahcal fistula.The urachus is an embryologic canal connecting the dome of the fetal bladder with the allantois, astructure that contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord. In this condition, there iscontinuous urinary drainage from the umbilicus on straining. It usually presents as a tender,swollen mass secondary to infection.Diagnosis is made by ultrasonography or computed tomography (CT).Definitive management is surgical resection of the tract.A patent vitellointestinal duct, patent omphalomesenteric duct and bladder diverticulum willcause umbilical discharge even in the absence of straining. The discharge in such a case iscomposed of the contents of the intestine (curdy white in colour mostly).

questions.question: On observing the following finding in the X-ray of a baby, what is the most likely diagnosisyou would suspect?
questions.explanation: The presence of a “double-bubble” sign on a plain abdominal radiograph is suggestive of adiagnosis of duodenal atresia. The double bubble is caused by the distension of stomach andproximal duodenum.Duodenal atresia results from failed recanalization of the intestinal lumen during gestation. Ahistory of polyhydramnios is present; half of the infants seen with duodenal atresia are premature.The hallmark of duodenal obstruction is bilious vomiting without abdominal distention, which isusually noted on the 1st day of life.364The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastricdecompression and intravenous fluid replacement. The typical surgical repair for duodenal atresiais duodenoduodenostomy.

questions.question: An infant was brought to the paediatrician with complaints of vomiting and abdominaldistention. The parents inform that the baby passes stools that look like currant jelly. Onultrasonography, a target sign was observed. Which of the following is not true about thiscondition?

options.A: Rota virus vaccine is not associated with increased risk
options.C: The most common cause is idiopathic
options.D: The most common location is ileocolic region353

questions.explanation: The clinical vignette is suggestive of intussusception and the rotavirus vaccine is associated withan increased risk, albeit only a slightly increased riskIntussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacentsegment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Ileoileal location is seenpostoperatively and in Henoch-Schönlein Purpura.90% of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infantsduring the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upperrespiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightlyincreased risk of intussusception.Lead points are more common in children older than 2 years of age and can cause recurrentintussusception. Some recognizable lead points are as follows: enlarged submucosal Peyer'spatch, Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, neurofibroma, intestinal duplication cysts,leiomyomas, hamartomas, anastomotic suture line, enterostomy tube, hemangioma, or malignantconditions such as lymphoma or Kaposi sarcoma.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child is admitted to your unit with recurrent pancreatitis. Which of the followingdevelopmental anomalies is likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly associated with recurrent pancreatitis.It is also the most common pancreatic developmental anomaly.It results from the failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds, due to which, thetail, body, and part of the head of the pancreas drain through the small accessory duct of Santorinirather than the main duct of Wirsung. It may be associated with recurrent pancreatitis.

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy was playing football with his friends during the PET classes. Suddenly hecomplained of severe abdominal pain and he is rushed to the pediatric ER. An erect X-rayscan of the abdomen showed the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Sigmoid volvulus is the most likely diagnosis. It occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on thesigmoid mesocolon. It is a cause of large bowel obstruction.

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severegeneralised abdominal pain associated with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. On354examination, his abdomen is tense with generalised tenderness, guarding and McBurnystenderness is present. No bowel sounds are present. What is the best diagnostic investigationin this child?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Ultrasound is the best diagnosticinvestigation in the evaluation of acute appendicitis and has demonstrated >90% sensitivityand specificity.365The advantages of ultrasound include its easy availability, rapid method, low cost, and freedomfrom ionizing radiation.The ultrasound criteria for appendicitis include the following:• Wall thickness ≥6 mm• Luminal distention•Lack of compressibility.• A complex mass in the right lower quadrant• Or an appendicolithImage: Ultrasound showing evidence of appendicitisSIEMENSD= 18.1mmPagBF125 mSMI 1.27.5L40/3.4Abdomen100%34dB7.0cmZD315B/sTHIMessenlitIM: 12

questions.question: Aaradhana, a 14-year-old girl is feeling embarrassed as she has to often rush to the restroomduring school hours. Her friends also make fun of her as she blushes frequently for no reason.She was later diagnosed with an appendicular tumour. Labs revealed low levels of niacin withthe tumour being positive for synaptophysin. Which of the following biochemical moietiescan be demonstrated in the patient's urine sample?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette is suggestive of a carcinoid tumour. Elevated levels of urinary 5-hydroxyindole acetic acid (5-HIAA) can be seen in this condition.The carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours arising from enterochromaffin cells that canoccur anywhere in the GIT. In children, they are most commonly seen in the appendix. Acarcinoid tumour with metastasis to the liver is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. The tumourelaborates serotonin, 5-HT, and histamine, which produce flushing (frequent blushing), waterydiarrhoea, bronchoconstriction, and right heart failure.Carcinoid syndrome can cause secondary niacin deficiency as they consume and divert thetryptophan NAD+ pathway to cause the overproduction of serotonin. Thus, these patients can alsohave pellagra like features.The diagnosis can be confirmed by elevated levels of urinary 5-HIAA.366The image attached above demonstrates islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pinkgranular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin.Synaptophysin is typically positive in carcinoid tumors.Treatment: Essentially surgical. Medical management includes the administration of somatostatinanalogues (octreotide).• Small tumours (<1 cm in size) are treated by appendectomy.• Larger tumours (>2 cm in size) require further bowel resection.

questions.question: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent colicky abdominal pain and melena. Onexamination, you note the following lesions in the buccal mucosa. You suspect Peutz-Jegherssyndrome and advice for the endoscopic investigation to look for polyps. In which part of theintestine would you expect to find maximum polyps?355
questions.explanation: The hamartomatous polyps in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are seen in order of prevalence:Jejunum > ileum > duodenum > colonic or gastric.

questions.question: A full-term neonate was found to have distention of the abdomen. He also passed hismeconium late and based on further workup was later diagnosed with Hirschsprung disease.Which of the following conditions is least likely to be found in association with this?
questions.explanation: Hirschsprung disease is not associated with Edward syndrome (trisomy 18).It is associated with:•Trisomy 21/ Downs syndrome•Joubert syndrome•Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome• Shah-Waardenburg syndrome• Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2 syndrome•Neurofibromatosis (Von recklinghausen disease)367• Neuroblastoma•Urogenital or cardiovascular abnormalities.3 FILMSUPINE4 FILMPRONERBARIUM ENEMARBARIUM ENEMAHirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglioncells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus. It is more common in males. Risk factors includeDown's syndrome and RET oncogene.The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiographwith barium or gastrograffin enema (image shown above).The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typicallyshows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transitionzone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel.A rectal suction biopsy is a gold standard for the diagnosis and operative intervention is thedefinitive treatment.•Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:⚫ Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis isperformed.• Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionatednormal colon is pulled posterior.• Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionicdistal rectum and then the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscularcuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.NOTE:In the fetus, migration of the neuronal crest tissues to form myenteric plexus and ganglion cells iscompleted by the 24th week of life. If interrupted in migration, it results in Hirschsprung disease.

questions.question: A neonate is being evaluated in the nursery for failure to pass meconium in the last 48 hours.Physical examination reveals abdominal distension and an anal dimple. Wangenstein'sinvertogram shows a low lying defect. Further evaluation reveals the presence of vertebraland renal deformities. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be seen in thischild?
questions.explanation: 368The given clinical vignette is suggestive of imperforate anus in a neonate with VACTERLassociation (presence of vertebral and renal anomalies in addition to the analatresia). Lymphedema is not a component of VACTERL syndrome.VACTERL association is a disorder that affects many-body systems. People diagnosedwith VACTERL association typically have at least three of the following characteristic features.Components of VACTERL association:• Vertebral• Anorectal• Cardiac• Tracheal• Esophageal• Renal•Radial•• Limb anomaliesAnorectal malformations:•• It occurs due to the post-allantoic gut with the proctodaeum.• Newborns classically present with inability to pass meconium within 48 hours, abdominaldistention, intestinal obstruction, improper anal dimple, and sometimes with complaints ofpassing meconium per urethra.Wingspread Classification:• Low - Below the level of the pelvic floor (puborectalis).• Intermediate - Occurs at the level of the puborectalis with or without fistula.•High Anorectal agenesis, rectal atresia.-Investigations:• Wangenstein's invertogram is done 6-12 hours after birth with a metal coin strapped to thepresumed site of the anus. The X-ray taken is used to measure and classify the deformity.• USG abdomen•Imaging to evacuate associated abnormalitiesTreatment is surgical.

questions.question: You notice a 5-year-old boy walking very differently in an orphanage. On probing further theguardian informs that he has a history of frequently soiling his pants. On examination, youfind a mass protruding through his anus and a diagnosis of rectal prolapse is made. Which ofthe following would be the most likely cause for this presentation?
questions.explanation: In this case, the most likely cause of rectal prolapse would be Trichuriasis. It is common in poorrural communities with inadequate sanitary facilities and soil contaminated with human oranimal feces. The highest infection rate occurs among children between 5-15 years.369Clinical manifestations include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmentaldeficits. In heavy infections, adult worms can extend throughout the colon down to the rectum.Over time, inflammation of the rectum causes tenesmus leading to prolapse.Other options:Pertussis would present with cough, low-grade fever, and sneezing. Increased abdominal pressuredue to the persistent cough could cause a prolapse.Chronic constipation is unlikely as the child has a history of frequently soiling his pants,suggestive of dysentery.Cystic fibrosis would manifest much earlier in life with respiratory symptoms like recurrentpneumonia. These children have exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, causing protein and fatmalabsorption. This leads to bulky, greasy stools and eventually a prolapse if untreated.370
